title: Italian Typography
content:
Can anyone help with the following examples of Italian typefaces? I'm hoping to identify both typefaces used in this beautiful signage. Thanks for the help!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623im_/http:/typophile.com/files/italiantype_3681.jpg)
author: pcarew

comments.content:
All hand done and all wonderful.  
Fabbrica - Similar forms in [Amity](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/sentinel/amity/?refby=typographica)  
Rip - Consider [Metroscript](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/alphabet_soup/metroscript_ot/?affid=99346)

[Houschka Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.type.co.uk/index.php?p=a_to_z_listing&let=*&id=6204) is close for Fabbrica.

Nick Cooke
Nice picture! “Riparazioni” doesn’t look like a typeface: look how all the “a”s and “i”s are different.

For Ripararioni you might also consider [Kinescope](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/mark_simonson/kinescope/?sample_text=Ripararioni&sample_size=36&acs_ss=-1&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1).

... and in some ways I am reminded of [Base 9 Small Caps](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/emigre/base_9_regular_sc/?sample_text=fabbrica&sample_size=36&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1), except the I ... that's off.
Wow, you guys are good. Thanks for the recommendations!

For those who came here later, maybe via search: Neutraface ( [http://www.houseind.com/fonts/neutraface](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123043623/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/neutraface "http://www.houseind.com/fonts/neutraface")) has somewhat similar retro feel, although capital A is very different.

To be honest, I think that the digital format typefaces you mentioned have little or nothing to do – culturally speaking, with the styles of lettering samples in the photo posted by pcarew.  
These are of course, example of custom-made lettering, and they are quintessentially italian. In such cases, if someone wants something similar, he might consider doing a research and design the letters he needs by himself.

I particularly think neither Metroscript nor Kinescope have anything to share with the style of the "Riparazioni" lettering line.
A side note: in terms of "handcraftedness" Houscka Black by Nick could do, as a starting point, because it's – of course – european more than "american".
